case_name: Dalip Singh v. State of Pepsu

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 235 of 1958 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 235 of 1958.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated October 18,1956 of the former PEPSU High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 11 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 18,1956, of the former PEPSU High Court in Regular First Appeal No. 11 of 1954,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment and decree dated November 21, 1953 of Additional District Judge, Patiala.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and decree dated November 21, 1953, of the Additional District Judge, Patiala.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on July 28, 1960 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. July 28. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-

facts.text: Appellant Dalip Singh entered service of Patiala State in 1916.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Dalip Singh entered the service of the Patiala State in 1916

facts.text: Rose to rank of Inspector General of Police of Patiala State in June 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and rose to the rank of Inspector General of Police of the State in June 1946.

facts.text: After formation of State of Pepsu, absorbed in Police Service and appointed Inspector General of Police.

anchor.surface_text: After the formation of the State of Pepsu he was absorbed in the Police Service of the newly formed State and was appointed

facts.text: Proceeded on leave from October 18, 1949 till August 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: and confirmed as Inspector General of Police thereof. While holding that post he proceeded on leave from October 18, 1949,

facts.text: Rajpramukh ordered retirement of Dalip Singh, IGP Pepsu, on leave, for administrative reasons w.e.f. August 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1950, an order was made by the Rajpramukh of the State in these words- His Highness the Rajpramukh is pleased to retire from service Sardar Dalip Singh,

facts.text: Copy of retirement order forwarded to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: A copy of this order was forwarded to the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant wrote to Chief Secretary on August 19, 1950, stating retirement causes loss of Rs. 50,000 and affects pension, tantamounts to removal.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon on August 19, 1950, the appellant wrote to the Chief Secretary of the State stating that by his retirement he would be put to heavy loss, i.e., about Rs. 50,000

facts.text: Government mentioned charges against him on March 30, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Ultimately on March 30, 1951, the Government mentioned the charges against him on the basis of which the Government had decided to retire him

facts.text: Appellant filed suit in Court of District Judge, Patiala against State of Pepsu after notice under s.80 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: After service of notice under s.80 of the Code of Civil Procedure the appellant brought a suit in the Court of the District Judge, Patiala, against the State of Pepsu

facts.text: Suit sought declaration that orders of August 18, 1950 are unconstitutional, illegal, void; still in service; arrears from Aug 18,1950; Rs. 26,699-13-0.

anchor.surface_text: asking for a declaration that the orders of August 16, 1950, and August 18, 1950, whereby the plaintiff has been removed from the post of Inspector- General of Police,

facts.text: Petitioner's main plea: order of Aug 18,1950 amounted to removal under Art. 311(2), provisions not complied with.

anchor.surface_text: The main plea on which the suit was based was that the order of August 18, 1950, amounted to his removal from service within the meaning of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution

facts.text: Respondent contended: plaintiff retired, not removed; Art. 311 not applicable.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent State contended that the plaintiff had been retired from service and had not been removed from service and so Art. 311 of the Constitution had no application.

facts.text: Trial Court held order compulsorily retiring plaintiff amounted to removal under Art. 311, not complied with; decreed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On this question the trial Court came to the conclusion that the order compulsorily retiring the plaintiff amounted to his removal within the meaning of Art. 311 of the Constitution

facts.text: PEPSU High Court disagreed, held compulsory retirement not removal under Art. 311; allowed appeal, dismissed suit.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the State the Pepsu High Court disagreeing with the Trial Court held that the order of compulsory retirement did not amount to removal

facts.text: Rule 278 of Patiala State Regulations: State reserves right to retire any employee on pension on political or other reasons.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 278 of the Patiala State Regulations was in the following words- For all classes of pensions the person who desires to obtain the pension is required to submit his application

facts.text: Rule 278 applicable on August 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1950, therefore it is reasonable to hold that Rule 278 in its entirety remained in force and was applicable to Pepsu.

facts.text: Appellant allowed full pension.

anchor.surface_text: Applying the other test, viz., whether the officer has lost the benefit he has earned, we find that the officer has been allowed full pension.

facts.text: Supreme Court held compulsory retirement under Rule 278 not removal under Art. 311.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that the order of compulsory retirement made against the appellant was not removal from service

facts.text: Patiala Service Regulations Vol. II (Travelling Allowance) published 1946.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that revised rules for Travelling Allowance were published in 1946 as Vol. II of the new rules,

facts.text: Pay and allowances rules published as Vol. I in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: and Rules relating to pay and allowances were published as Vol. I in 1947.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1950, therefore it is reasonable to hold that Rule 278 in its entirety remained in force and was applicable to Pepsu.

arguments.claim: Compulsory retirement under service rules like Rule 278 not removal under Art. 311 if passes Shyamlal tests

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the termination of service by companypulsory retirement in accordance with Service Rules amount to removal from service was companysidered by his Court in Shyamlal v. The State of U. P. and the Union of India  1  and again recently in State of Bombay V. Subhagchand D08hi  2 .

arguments.claim: First Shyamlal test: action not by way of punishment as no charge/imputation condition for exercise of power

anchor.surface_text: The first is whether the action is by way of punishment and to find that out the Court said that it was necessary that a charge or imputation against the officer is made the companydition of the exercise of the power

arguments.claim: Applied to facts: order not based on any charge, stated administrative reasons; charges communicated only later at insistence

anchor.surface_text: In the case before us the order of the Rajpramukh does number purport to be passed on any charge of misconduct or inefficiency. All it states is that the companypulsory retirement is for administrative reasons.

arguments.claim: Second Shyamlal test: no loss of earned benefits as full pension granted

anchor.surface_text: Applying the other test, viz., whether the officer has lost the benefit he has earned, we find that the officer has been allowed full pension. There is numberquestion of his having lost a benefit earned.

arguments.claim: Rule 278 provides for retirement on pension, so not punitive

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that Rule 278 itself provides for retirement on pension. If the provision had been for retirement without pension in accordance with the rules there might have been some reason to hold that the retirement was by way of punishment.

arguments.claim: Observation in Doshi case does not require compulsory retirement rule to fix age; not limited to that

anchor.surface_text: We do number think that was what the Court intended to say in Doshis Case 2 . In Doshis Case 3  there was in fact a rule fixing an age for companypulsory retirement, at the age of 55, and in addition another rule for companypulsory retirement after an officer had companypleted the age of 50 or 25 years of service.

arguments.claim: Retirement decision tantamount to removal as causes heavy financial loss and affects pension

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon on August 19, 1950, the appellant wrote to the Chief Secretary of the State stating that by his retirement he would be put to heavy loss, i.e., about Rs. 50,000 which he would have earned as his pay and allowances etc., during this period and that his pension was also being affected and that this decision of the Government tantamounts to his removal from service.

arguments.court_reasoning: Full pension granted, no loss of earned benefits

holdings.text: Rule 278 of the Patiala State Regulations remained in force and was applicable to Pepsu on August 18, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: On August 18, 1950, therefore it is reasonable to hold that Rule 278 in its entirety remained in force and was applicable to Pepsu.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pension rules from 1931 edition continued applicable as no revision before 1950; 1952 publication confirms continuity.

holdings.text: The order of compulsory retirement made against the appellant was not removal from service so as to attract the provisions of Art. 311 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that the order of compulsory retirement made against the appellant was not removal from service

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied two tests from Shyamlal case: not punitive (no charge as condition precedent to power exercise); no loss of earned benefits (full pension granted).

holdings.text: Compulsory retirement in accordance with service rules like Rule 278 does not amount to removal from service under Art. 311 if it passes the Shyamlal tests.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether the termination of service by compulsory retirement in accordance with Service Rules amount to removal from service was considered by this Court in Shyamlal v.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Followed Shyamlal and Doshi precedents establishing two-factor test for distinguishing compulsory retirement from removal/dismissal.

holdings.text: The compulsory retirement order was not by way of punishment as no charge or imputation against the officer was made the condition of the exercise of the power.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Order cited administrative reasons only; charges communicated later at appellant's insistence, not basis for order; Rule 278 permits retirement on pension for political/other reasons.

holdings.text: By the compulsory retirement the officer did not lose any benefit he had already earned.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Full pension granted as per rules; Rule 278 provides for pension, distinguishing from punitive measures without benefits.

holdings.text: The observations in Doshi's case do not lay down that compulsory retirement under a rule like Rule 278 must be regarded as dismissal or removal under Art. 311.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Doshi context involved age/service-based rules; not addressing open-ended rules like Rule 278; improper to extend observation beyond context.
